title: Quotation of the Day: What is Justice? One Parkland Family’s Agonizing Journey.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 24, 2022.
content: “For such a long time, you are raising your kids, and that feels like your purpose. And then suddenly, one day, one of your purposes is gone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasper Williams-Ward and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: At Least 17 Migrants Die After Boat Capsizes Off Bahamas
description: The tragedy highlights migrants’ growing use of dangerous sea routes to reach the United States.
content: NASSAU, the Bahamas — At least 17 Haitians, including a child, died Sunday after their boat capsized off the Bahamas on its way to Florida, the latest tragedy amid a spike in the number of migrants trying to reach the United States by sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: American Women Run Away with Gold in the 4x100-Meters. American Men Settle for Silver.
description: Christian Coleman, Noah Lyles, Elijah Hall and Marvin Bracy settled for silver after a botched handoff exchange.
content: In another men’s relay hindered by a butchered handoff exchange, the U.S. settled for a silver medal in Saturday’s 4x100-meter relay. They finished in 37.55 seconds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: ‘An abyss of fear’: A report accuses Russia of further abuses against civilians.
description: Human Rights Watch cataloged a litany of torture, inhumane treatment, arbitrary detention and disappearances in southern Ukraine and said that the atrocities could amount to war crimes.
content: Russian forces have tortured and beaten civilians in the areas of southern Ukraine that they control, part of a series of abuses that may amount to war crimes, Human Rights Watch said this weekend in a report that further undermined the public case repeatedly made by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia for the invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Cumming
title: Five Cocktails to Help Beat the Heat
description: Bartenders based in New York City, Miami, London, Paris and Barcelona provide drink recipes perfect for high summer.
content: When it comes to entertaining, drinks can be trickier than food. Anyone can have a surprising salad ingredient or a closely guarded low ’n ’slow barbecue procedure. Far fewer hosts think outside the wine-beer-soda box. But it can be done. Here, five leading international bartenders and mixologists share creative summer drink recipes you could easily make and that, whether for a riff on a Waldorf salad or a strawberry spritzer, will keep your guests cool, refreshed and, perhaps most importantly, impressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong
title: On U.S. Foreign Policy, the New Boss Acts a Lot Like the Old One
description: The Biden administration has charted the same course as the Trump administration on strategic priorities like China, the Middle East and U.S. military deployments.
content: WASHINGTON — A fist bump and meeting with the crown prince of Saudi Arabia. Tariffs and export controls on China. Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. American troops out of Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Carleton Varney, Interior Designer Known as Mr. Color, Dies at 85
description: He was trained by the maximalist decorator Dorothy Draper, who favored bold colors, and he inherited her aversion to the bland and the beige.
content: Carleton Varney, the ebullient interior designer whose enthusiastic use of color in hotels, castles, palaces and the habitats of film and theater royalty — and one president — earned him the nickname Mr. Color, died on July 14 in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: ‘The Silent Woman,’ an Opera About Putting on an Opera
description: Bard SummerScape unveiled a rare staging of Richard Strauss’s opera, composed amid the Nazis’ rise to power.
content: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — “Ha! A silent woman?,” sings the basso buffo Morosus in Richard Strauss’s “Die Schweigsame Frau.” “You’ll only find her in a churchyard under a stone cross.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: One of two Americans who recently died in Ukraine was called to volunteer by his heritage, a close friend says.
description: Going to join in the fight ‘was something that he needed to do,’ the friend said.
content: A Ukrainian commander over the weekend identified two Americans who were recently killed in the nation’s eastern Donbas region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf and Emile Ducke
title: ‘We Survived Another Night’: In Ruined Suburb, Solace in a Small Community
description: In a largely abandoned apartment complex on the outskirts of Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-biggest city, the people who stayed behind find comfort in their surroundings and each other.
content: SALTIVKA, Ukraine — On a recent Saturday morning, Yevhenia Botiyeva weeded the flower bed outside her apartment building, a routine she has taken on since she returned home in late spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Triple-Digit Temperatures Break Records in the Northeast
description: Daily record highs were set in cities along the East Coast, including Boston and Newark, which was on its fifth day of triple-digit temperatures.
content: Several cities in the Northeast saw record-high daily temperatures on Sunday as a nationwide scorching peaked in many places around the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: There’s More Than One Way to Ban a Book
description: A serious strain of self-censorship has taken root within the left-leaning publishing industry.
content: In the 1950s, Vladimir Nabokov’s “Lolita” was banned in France, Britain and Argentina, but not in the United States, where its publisher, Walter Minton, released the book after multiple American publishing houses rejected it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Heat Waves Sweep the Northeast Over Sweltering Weekend
description: Newark sets a record with five straight days of temperatures above 100 degrees, and other parts of the country, like Oklahoma, also experienced triple-digit heat.
content: Scorching temperatures swept the Northeast on Sunday in the region’s first prolonged heat wave of the summer, with a record-breaking five straight days of triple-digit temperatures in Newark and blistering heat in Boston; Providence, R.I.; and Manchester, N.H.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: No More Pet Store Puppies? New York May Finally Ban Sales.
description: A bill prohibiting the sale of dogs, cats and rabbits in New York pet stores, passed by the Legislature in June, awaits a decision from Gov. Kathy Hochul.
content: Hundreds of postcards, with visceral images of underfed golden retriever puppies living in filthy conditions, are flooding the governor’s office in New York. A huge email campaign has been launched by national animal rights groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: All the Pieces Seemed to Align for the Liberty Except One: Winning
description: Despite a more stable home at Barclays Center in Brooklyn, a new coach and stars in place, the team has struggled with injuries and gaining traction in the competitive New York sports market.
content: The Liberty had seemingly done everything right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Alanis Thames
title: Pretty in Any Color: Women on the Court Make the Style Rules
description: Players in women’s basketball are styling themselves how they want, because they can. Their choices also can be lucrative.
content: Angel Reese considers herself “a pink kind of girl.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Maggie Rogers’s Higher Calling
description: Musicians often talk about seeking the divine in their work. The 28-year-old singer-songwriter went to Harvard to study it as she made her second major-label album, “Surrender.”
content: Like a lot of artists during the early days of the pandemic, Maggie Rogers was living a sequestered, solitary life. She had retreated to coastal Maine, trying to alleviate the burnout of touring for her 2019 major-label debut “Heard It In a Past Life,” with little plan to write. “I was hiding out,” she said. “At a complete loss for words.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: This Week in Business: Amazon’s Latest Acquisition
description: Netflix reports a drop in subscribers, but it could have been worse. The Fed announces its next rate increase. And we’ll hear how strong, or weak, the U.S. economy is.
content: It is theoretically possible to go through a day patronizing only Amazon-owned companies: You might buy groceries at Whole Foods, listen to a book on Audible on your commute, check your Goodreads account and then, of course, visit Amazon.com. Now, the e-commerce giant is making a new push into health care. Amazon announced on Thursday that it had reached a $3.9 billion deal to buy One Medical, a network of primary care clinics, as part of its quest to become a major player in the industry. The deal is the first acquisition under Andy Jassy, who became chief executive a year ago after Jeff Bezos stepped down. Mr. Jassy’s approach to the role has been much different from his predecessor’s, but on this decision, he hasn’t diverged too drastically from Mr. Bezos. One Medical is not the first health-care-related company Amazon has purchased. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: ‘Parentese’ Is Truly a Lingua Franca, Global Study Finds
description: In an ambitious cross-cultural study, researchers found that adults around the world speak and sing to babies in similar ways.
content: We’ve all seen it, we’ve all cringed at it, we’ve all done it ourselves: talked to a baby like it was, you know, a baby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Seagull’ Review: Blurring the Lines of Fiction
description: Elevator Repair Service’s Chekhov revival has promising ideas about art, experimentation and truth, but the production inevitably falls flat, our critic writes.
content: If only I could find someone who loves me enough to gift me a dead bird in a brown paper bag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden’s Covid Symptoms Continue to Improve, Doctor Says
description: Public health officials have pointed to his case — which an adviser said was caused by BA.5 — as a reminder of the risk posed by the highly transmissible subvariant.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden continues to “improve significantly” after testing positive for the coronavirus on Thursday, his physician, Dr. Kevin O’Connor, said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Anton Troianovski and Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Russia Tells Famine-Fearing Africa It’s Not to Blame for Food Shortage
description: Badly needed grain has been piling up in Ukrainian ports since Moscow invaded, but Russia’s top diplomat is in Africa saying the West is to blame.
content: CAIRO — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia likes to cast himself as the leader of a global movement rising up against domination by the United States and its allies. On Sunday, his top diplomat brought that message directly to Africa, hoping to turn the hunger and social strife across the continent to Russia’s advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seeks Support in Africa
description: Also, the W.H.O. declares monkeypox a global emergency and China launches a rocket into space.
content: Russia’s top diplomat, Sergey Lavrov, set off on a tour of four African countries — Egypt, Ethiopia, Uganda and the Republic of Congo — seeking to place blame on the West for war-related grain shortages that have sparked fears of famine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Fears rise for a rights activist captured while fighting for Ukraine.
description: Russian propaganda has demonized Maksym Butkevych, a former journalist and campaigner who was taken prisoner in the eastern city of Sievierodonetsk.
content: Maksym Butkevych made his name in Ukraine as a journalist and human rights activist, campaigning on behalf of refugees and internally displaced people and serving on the board of Ukraine’s chapter of Amnesty International.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 24, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 24, 2022.
content: An article last Sunday about the perform­ance of municipal bonds this year referred incorrectly to the state tax deductibility of income from nationwide municipal bond funds for residents of California. For Califor­nia residents, the deductibility depends on the amount that a particular fund invests in California municipal bonds and U.S. Treas­uries; California residents would not get a deduction in every case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Marvel Studios Unveils ‘Black Panther: Wakanda Forever’
description: The studio announced news of the film’s release on Saturday at the pop-culture convention Comic-Con International in San Diego.
content: Marvel Studios has unveiled a trailer for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” — the long-awaited sequel to its hit film “Black Panther” — which it said would open in cinemas in the United States on Nov. 11.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Lim
title: Bob Rafelson, Director of ‘Five Easy Pieces,’ Dies at 89
description: A central figure in the New Hollywood movement, he was also the co-creator of the TV pop group the Monkees and featured it in a movie, “Head.”
content: Bob Rafelson, an iconoclastic director and producer who was a central figure of the New Hollywood movement that jump-started American cinema in the wake of the 1960s counterculture upheavals, died on Saturday at his home in Aspen, Colo. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Diana Kennedy, Authority on Mexican Cooking, Dies at 99
description: Her books taught Americans about the regional nature of the cuisine. Also: “There is always someone who wants to know how to clean an iguana, so why not?”
content: Diana Kennedy, an Englishwoman whose 1972 cookbook “The Cuisines of Mexico” revealed the glories of regional Mexican fare to American readers, died on Sunday at her home in Michoacán, Mexico. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Dionne Searcey
title: Congo to Auction Land to Oil Companies: ‘Our Priority Is Not to Save the Planet’
description: Peatlands and rainforests in the Congo Basin protect the planet by storing carbon. Now, in a giant leap backward for the climate, they’re being auctioned off for drilling.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — The Democratic Republic of Congo, home to one of the largest old-growth rainforests on earth, is auctioning off vast amounts of land in a push to become “the new destination for oil investments,” part of a global shift as the world retreats on fighting climate change in a scramble for fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here’s what to watch at the world championships on Sunday.
description: Catch the men’s 5,000 meters, the women’s 800 meters and the women’s 4x400-meters.
content: We’ve arrived at the final day of the world championships here in Eugene, Ore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz
title: Last Stand at Azovstal: Inside the Siege That Shaped the Ukraine War
description: For 80 days, at a sprawling steelworks, a relentless Russian assault met unyielding Ukrainian resistance. This is how it was for those who fought, and for those trapped beneath the battlefield.
content: The two Mi-8 helicopters tore across enemy territory early on the morning of March 21, startling the Russian soldiers below. Inside were Ukrainian Special Forces fighters carrying crates of Stinger and Javelin missiles, as well as a satellite internet system. They were flying barely 20 feet above ground into the hottest combat zone in the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Blair, Jack D'Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Corey Schreppel and Zachary Mouton
title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Books About Sex That Every Family Should Read’
description: The author Cory Silverberg bucks decades of conventional wisdom on how to teach children about intimacy.
content: How do you teach your child about sex? It’s a perennial question that has spawned hundreds of illustrated books meant to demystify sexual intercourse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle, Kevin Draper and Benjamin Mullin
title: Why Big Tech Is Making a Big Play for Live Sports
description: Competing for rights to broadcast games from the N.F.L. and other leagues could be hard for broadcast and cable companies that “aren’t playing by the same financial rules.”
content: LOS ANGELES — More than a decade after Apple disrupted the music industry and Amazon upended retail, the tech heavyweights have set their sights on a new arena ripe for change: live sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: After Recent Turmoil, the Race for Texas Governor Is Tightening
description: A series of tragedies and challenges have soured the mood of Texans and made the governor’s race perhaps the most competitive since the 1990s.
content: SUGAR LAND, Texas — One of the deadliest school shootings in U.S. history. The revival of a 1920s ban on abortion. The country’s worst episode of migrant death in recent memory. And an electrical grid, which failed during bitter cold, now straining under soaring heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: We Can’t Afford Not to Prosecute Trump
description: He will never willingly walk away from the presidency. It was the greatest grift of his life.
content: We all learn from failure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Jonas Vingegaard Wins Tour de France, Completing His Sudden Ascent to Top
description: Vingegaard, 25, won cycling’s most prestigious race on his second attempt, setting up a new rivalry with the two-time champion he dethroned, Tadej Pogacar.
content: PARIS — Head down and legs churning, Jonas Vingegaard crossed the finish line of the penultimate stage of the Tour de France on Saturday and cupped his hand over his mouth, as if to stifle a gasp. He had done what he had come to do, and his astonishing accomplishment was sinking in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randal C. Archibold
title: Huff, Pant, Sweat: High Heat Shortens the New York City Triathlon
description: Organizers take more precautions for athletes, volunteers and emergency workers.
content: Excessive heat disrupted the New York City Triathlon on Sunday, forcing organizers to shorten the race and make other accommodations for safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: What Prancer and Dancer Do
description: Michael T. Buerke makes his New York Times Crossword debut, and he may be familiar to some of our readers.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — It never fails to make me smile when a crossword solver decides to try constructing a puzzle. This evolution from player to game maker is special, because it shows that the person is deeply invested and sees crosswords as more than just two-dimensional tests of vocabulary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Finding the Heat in ‘Sacred Earth’
description: At Ragamala Dance Company’s nature-themed performance at BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn!, the strongest connection was between music and dance, our critic writes.
content: At BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn! on Friday night, the air was muggy but periodically cooled by breezes. “Sacred Earth,” the work that Ragamala Dance Company performed in the Lena Horne Bandshell in Prospect Park, felt like the reverse: mostly mild with some hotter currents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: For the Hall of Fame’s New Class, Timing Was Everything
description: While David Ortiz sailed in as a first-ballot Hall of Famer, the year’s other new inductees had to wait for decades — four did not live to see the honor.
content: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. — When John Jordan “Buck” O’Neil Jr. wrote his memoir, in 1996, he called it “I Was Right On Time.” It was a challenging, counterintuitive title for the life story of a man barred from playing Major League Baseball because of his skin color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: ‘Everybody Is Dug In’: Kansans Fiercely Debate the First Post-Roe Vote on Abortion
description: The Aug. 2 ballot question will decide whether the State Constitution will allow legislators to ban or further restrict the procedure.
content: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. — Kansas voters will decide next week whether to remove protections of abortion rights from their State Constitution, providing the first electoral test of Americans’ attitudes on the issue since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: Too Many New Yorkers Can’t Swim. It’s Time to Change That.
description: New York City is letting down its residents by nixing swimming lessons.
content: When sharks began appearing along New York beaches this summer, officials sprang into action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: Sri Lanka’s Uprising
description: What led to the recent protests.
content: Sri Lanka’s recent upheaval offers an extreme example of the world’s recent problems. Covid disrupted the country’s major industries, particularly tourism, and then leaders failed to adapt — setting off a chain of economic calamities, including food and fuel shortages. The crisis prompted protests, culminating in the president’s resignation and the installation of a new president on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Libby Peterson
title: Conceptual Covers That Push the Conversation
description: The creative director of The New York Times Magazine explains her team’s approach to visualizing each issue and shares how they decide to take risks.
content: Asked how far in advance she works on a cover of The New York Times Magazine, Gail Bichler paused to let herself be amused by the question, laughed and said: “Like, what do I want it to be?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: A French University Confronts Medical Crimes and Its Nazi Past
description: A report on the University of Strasbourg’s takeover by Nazis during World War II and on medical crimes they committed there sheds light on a period that had been mostly scrubbed from official memory.
content: STRASBOURG, France — For decades, students at the prestigious University of Strasbourg swapped rumors that human remains from Nazi victims, preserved as anatomical or pathological specimens, were still somewhere on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Edward Feiner, 75, Dies; Revolutionized the Look of Federal Buildings
description: As the government’s chief architect, he prioritized good design in the construction of hundreds of courthouses and office buildings.
content: Edward A. Feiner, who as the chief architect of the U.S. government revolutionized the public image of countless federal agencies by hiring renowned architects to design hundreds of courthouses, government laboratories, border stations and office buildings, died on July 1 at a nursing facility in Falls Church, Va. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steph Herold
title: From ‘Dirty Dancing’ to ‘Scandal,’ On-Screen Abortion Stories Carry Sway
description: Abortion is common and safe, but you might not know it from watching TV or movies.
content: In the weeks since the fall of Roe v. Wade, people have supported abortion access and rights in many ways, including spreading information about abortion pills and defending brave doctors. My contribution has been thinking about TV and movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Jane Perlez
title: Wait Begins for Falling 23-Ton Rocket Booster After China Space Station Launch
description: China successfully docked a new lab module to its space station. But no one knows where debris will land from the rocket stage that sent it to orbit.
content: Another big Chinese rocket launched to space on Sunday at 2:22 p.m. Beijing time, and once again, no one knows where or when it will come down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The High Point Was Sitting on Our Grandmother’s Deck’
description: Remembering the 1964 World’s Fair, an aloe plant at the bus stop and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zia ur-Rehman, Christina Goldbaum and Salman Masood
title: Pakistan’s Deadly Flood Season Worsened by Climate Change and Bad Infrastructure
description: Monsoon rains have devastated Pakistan’s economic hub, Karachi, adding urgency to pleas to better equip cities to handle more frequent extreme weather.
content: KARACHI, Pakistan — Year after year in Kausar Niazi Colony, a slum in the port city of Karachi, Murtaza Hussain and his neighbors watched as monsoon rains flooded into their homes, damaging furniture, televisions and other precious valuables.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen, Ted Clifford, Camellia Burris and Anna Watts
title: He Runs a New York Real Estate Empire. Did He Steal It?
description: Homeowners across the city say they were swindled out of their properties. But courts have been slow to act.
content: Over the past dozen years, Sanford Solny has built a New York real estate empire, snatching up small residential buildings across the city that churn out hundreds of thousands of dollars in rent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: As Jan. 6 Panel’s Evidence Piled Up, Conservative Media Doubled Down
description: Many of Donald J. Trump’s allies in the media believe the reports about violence and criminal conduct committed by Trump supporters have been exaggerated.
content: After the Jan. 6 committee’s final summer hearing last week, the talk on the sets of CNN and MSNBC turned to an intriguing if familiar possibility about what might result from the panel’s finding. The case for a criminal prosecution of former President Donald J. Trump, many pundits said, was not only justified but seemed more than likely given the evidence of his inaction as rioters sacked the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Rick Rojas
title: Mississippi Fires Lawyer Trying to Recoup Misused Welfare Funds
description: The lawyer had issued a subpoena that could reveal details about the involvement of a former governor and a football star in the scandal.
content: ATLANTA — A lawyer working for a Mississippi state agency and trying to recoup tens of millions of dollars in misused welfare funds was fired on Friday after he issued a subpoena that could turn up details about the involvement of prominent Mississippians — including the former Governor Phil Bryant and the retired football star Brett Favre — in one of the ugliest scandals to shake the nation’s poorest state in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Ties Between Alex Jones and Radio Network Show Economics of Misinformation
description: The Genesis Communications Network built a lucrative business alongside the radio host, whose show the company has syndicated for more than two decades.
content: Ted Anderson, a precious metals seller, was hoping to rustle up some business for his gold and silver dealership when he started a radio network out of a Minneapolis suburb a couple of decades ago. Soon after, he signed a brash young radio host named Alex Jones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denny Lee
title: It’s Getting Hot in Here
description: Some of the best looks from the parties held for Kith, Kenzo, Shayne Oliver and the Ali Forney Center.
content: Fashion took over the party scene last week. Kith, the sneaker retail temple, unveiled its collaboration with Spider-Man, who turned 60, with a pop-up store in Queens that featured limited-edition hoodies, sweaters, T-shirts and skateboards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Oregon athletes find a creative way to make money: Housing rentals.
description: Now that college athletes can profit from their fame, some University of Oregon runners are getting paid to help visitors staying in town for the track and field world championships.
content: As the track and field world championships made their first appearance in the U.S. at Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., this month, some University of Oregon athletes decided to creatively capitalize on their fame and the lack of abundant housing in this quaint college town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope to Offer a Long-Sought Apology to Canada’s Indigenous People
description: Pope Francis will travel to an Indigenous community in Canada to apologize for the church’s role in residential schools that tried to erase Indigenous culture, and where thousands of children died.
content: OTTAWA — Pope Francis is traveling to Canada this week to ​apologize to ​Indigenous communities for the Roman Catholic Church’s role in ​the country’s notorious residential school system, ​​where thousands of Indigenous children died, and countless others were sexually and physically abused.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Ease into things with casual but fun Chicago-style hot dogs, then make plans for pantry pasta and kung pao chicken later on.
content: Good morning. Not for me the long-simmered Sunday sauce and meatballs, at least not at the end of a sweaty summer weekend. I go big on Saturday nights this time of year, smoking meat and making pizzas over live fire, steaming clams and corn, assembling platters of tomatoes, serving buckles and watermelon. When Sunday evening arrives, tapping at its watch and pointing out what’s on the schedule for Monday, I’m eager for simplicity.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New Breastfeeding Guidelines: Helpful or Ill Timed?
description: Readers discuss Jessica Grose’s criticisms of a new American Academy of Pediatrics policy statement. Also: An uneasy feeling in the world; military recruits.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
